1.text: Canst thou draw out leviathan with a fish-hook? Or press down his tongue with a cord?

2.text: Canst thou put a ring into his nose? Or bore his jaw through with a hook?

3.text: Will he make many supplications unto thee? Or will he speak soft words unto thee?

4.text: Will he make a covenant with thee, That thou shouldest take him for a servant for ever?

5.text: Wilt thou play with him as with a bird? Or wilt thou bind him for thy maidens?

6.text: Will the bands of fishermen make a banquet of him? Will they part him among the merchants?

7.text: Canst thou fill his skin with barbed irons? Or his head with fish-spears?

8.text: Lay thy hand upon him; Think upon the battle, thou wilt do so no more.

9.text: Behold, the hope of him is in vain; Shall not one be cast down even at the sight of him?

10.text: None is so fierce that dare stir him up; Who then is able to stand before Me?

11.text: Who hath given Me anything beforehand, that I should repay him? Whatsoever is under the whole heaven is Mine.

12.text: Would I keep silence concerning his boastings, Or his proud talk, or his fair array of words?

13.text: Who can uncover the face of his garment? Who shall come within his double bridle?

14.text: Who can open the doors of his face? Round about his teeth is terror.

15.text: His scales are his pride, Shut up together as with a close seal.

16.text: One is so near to another, That no air can come between them.

17.text: They are joined one to another; They stick together, that they cannot be sundered.

18.text: His sneezings flash forth light, And his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.

19.text: Out of his mouth go burning torches, And sparks of fire leap forth.

20.text: Out of his nostrils goeth smoke, As out of a seething pot and burning rushes.

21.text: His breath kindleth coals, And a flame goeth out of his mouth.

22.text: In his neck abideth strength, And dismay danceth before him.

23.text: The flakes of his flesh are joined together; They are firm upon him; they cannot be moved.

24.text: His heart is as firm as a stone; Yea, firm as the nether millstone.

25.text: When he raiseth himself up, the mighty are afraid; By reason of despair they are beside themselves.

26.text: If one lay at him with the sword, it will not hold; Nor the spear, the dart, nor the pointed shaft.

27.text: He esteemeth iron as straw, And brass as rotten wood.

28.text: The arrow cannot make him flee; Slingstones are turned with him into stubble.

29.text: Clubs are accounted as stubble; He laugheth at the rattling of the javelin.

30.text: Sharpest potsherds are under him; He spreadeth a threshing-sledge upon the mire.

31.text: He maketh the deep to boil like a pot; He maketh the sea like a seething mixture.

32.text: He maketh a path to shine after him; One would think the deep to be hoary.

33.text: Upon earth there is not his like Who is made to be fearless.

34.text: He looketh at all high things; He is king over all the proud beasts.
